image_caption.he: סביבון מאת משה מורו. 1929

description.en: Haman is the villain of the [book of Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/Esther). A vizier of King [Ahasuerus](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/ahasuerus?sort=Relevance&), he planned a genocide against the Jewish people, but his plans were thwarted by [Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/esther) and her uncle, [Mordekhai](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mordekhai?tab=sources). As a descendant of the nation of [Amalek](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/amalek?tab=sources), the first nation to attack the Israelites soon after they left Egypt, Haman comes from a long line of enemies of the Jewish people.
description.he: המן הוא הרשע במגילת אסתר והבכיר בין שרי המלך אחשוורוש. הוא תכנן לבצע רצח עם שבו יושמדו היהודים בכל מדינות המלך אחשוורוש. תוכניתו סוכלה על ידי מרדכי ואסתר.

description.en: Leadership is a concept that features throughout the Jewish textual tradition. Biblical stories of leaders like the matriarchs and patriarchs, Moses, and Joshua, offer much material for leadership analysis. Rabbinic sources throughout the ages debate the merits of different models of leadership, and contemporary authors grapple with how to approach leadership today in light of ancient texts.

description.en: Stories of the world's creation appears in the first two chapters of the book of Genesis. Generations of Jewish thinkers have spilled much ink analyzing the meaning and significance of these chapters.

Miriam was a prophetess who, along with her brothers, [Moses](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/moses?sort=Relevance&tab=sources) and [Aaron](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/aaron?tab=sources), led the Israelites out of Egypt. She led the Jewish women in song and dance. According to midrashic stories, a well of fresh water followed the Israelites in the desert in her merit and disappeared upon her death.
description.he: מרים היא נביאה מקראית, ויחד עם אחיה משה ואהרן הנהיגה את בני ישראל בדרכם במדבר. היא הובילה את הנשים בשיר ובריקוד אחרי קריעת ים סוף. על פי המדרש, בזכותה ליוותה באר מים חיים את בני ישראל במסעותיהם במדבר, והבאר שקעה ונעלמה עם מותה.

description.en: The Mishkan (in English, Tabernacle) was the temporary, portable Temple that the Jews were commanded to build after the revelation at [Mount Sinai](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mount-sinai?tab=sources). It had all of the furnishings of the future Temple and served the same functions, but it was smaller and used fabrics and animal skins for its walls and roof.
description.he: המשכן היה המקדש הנייד והזמני שבני ישראל הצטוו לבנות אחרי ההתגלות בהר סיני. המשכן והמקדש מילאו את אותו התפקיד וכן שימשו בהם אותם הכלים, אך המשכן היה קטן יותר וקירותיו וגגו היו עשויים עורות ובדים.

image_caption.en: A sacrifice taking place in the tabernacle in the wilderness; the encampments of the Jewish tribes spread out to the horizon. Coloured lithograph. Wellcome Collection.
image_caption.he: קורבן במשכן במדבר; המחנות של שבטי ישראל מתפשטים עד לאופק. ליתוגרפיה צבעונית. מקור: אוסף ולקאם.

description.en: Jeremiah is one of the major Jewish prophets. He warned of the coming destruction of Jerusalem by Babylon as punishment for the sins of Israel but was mocked and ignored. After the destruction of the First Temple and Jerusalem in 586 BCE, he went into exile alongside many other Judeans. The books of Jeremiah and Lamentations are traditionally attributed to him.
description.he: ירמיהו הוא אחד הנביאים הבולטים במקרא. הוא הזהיר את העם שירושלים תיחרב על ידי הבבלים כעונש על חטאי עם ישראל, אך העם לעג לו והתעלם מדבריו. עם חורבן ירושלים גלה ירמיהו לבבל עם רבים מבני יהודה. מקובל לייחס לו את כתיבת ספר ירמיהו וספר איכה.

image_caption.en: Jeremiah, Ephraim Moses Lilien
image_caption.he: ירמיהו, אפרים משה ליליאן

description.en: Benjamin was the youngest son of Jacob. His mother Rachel died giving birth to him. He was especially beloved of Jacob and when he and his brothers traveled to Egypt to ask for food, Joseph accused Benjamin of stealing from him. Benjamin's brothers defended him, showing that they'd changed and grown.
description.he: בנימין הוא הצעיר בבני יעקב, בן זקונים לאביו. אימו רחל מתה בלידתו. הוא היה אהוב במיוחד על יעקב. כאשר נסע עם אֶחיו למצרים לבקש אוכל, יוסף, שהיה המשנה למלך מצרים, האשים אותו בגנבה. יתר אחיו הגנו עליו בהפגנת נאמנות שהעידה על שינוי בגישתם כלפי בני רחל.

image_caption.en: The Cup Found, James Tissot, 1896-1902
image_caption.he: מציאת הגביע, ג'יימס טיסו, 1896-1902

description.en: Ezra was a priest who, when the Persians conquered the Babylonian empire and allowed the Jews to return, led the Jews to Israel and in rebuilding the Temple. He instituted a series of reforms meant to bring the Jewish people back to their religion.
description.he: עזרא הוא כוהן בתקופת שיבת ציון. אחרי כיבוש בבל על ידי הפרסים, התיר כורש מלך פרס ליהודים לשוב לארץ ישראל ולבנות מחדש את בית המקדש. עזרא עמד בראשם והנהיג סדרה של רפורמות שנועדה להשיב את היהודים למסורת הדתית שלהם.

image_caption.en: Ezra reading the Law for the people. Nehemiah 8:5-6. Gustave Doré's illustrations for La Grande Bible de Tours, 1866
image_caption.he: Ezra reading the Law for the people. Nehemiah 8:5-6. Gustave Doré's illustrations for La Grande Bible de Tours, 1866

description.en: Balaam is a non-Israelite biblical prophet whose story appears in the book of Numbers. As the Israelites are wandering in the desert, the Moabite King Balak pays him to curse the Israelites. Balaam, however, is only able to speak the words that God puts in his mouth and ends up blessing the Israelites instead.
description.he: בלעם בן בעור הוא נביא מקראי שאינו מבני ישראל. בשעת נדודי בני ישראל במדבר שילם לו בלק מלך מואב שיקלל את בני ישראל. הוא הצליח להוציא מפיו רק את המילים שהאל שם בפיו, וכך בסופו של דבר בירך את עם ישראל במקום לקללו.

image_caption.en: Bala'am and his Donkey, Ephraim Moses Lilien. Before 1925.
image_caption.he: בלעם והאתון, אפרים משה ליליאן. לפני 1925

description.en: Rav Chiya b.Ashi was a student of Rav and was his personal assistant. Hence he was able to pass on many accounts of Rav's practices, which were used as legal precedents.
description.he: רב חייא בר אשי היה תלמידו של רב ועוזרו האישי. לפיכך היה ביכולתו למסור עדויות רבות על מנהגיו של רב – עדויות שנעשה בהן שימוש לצורך תקדימים הלכתיים.

description.en: R. Yishmael b. Yose studied under his father, R. Yose b. Chalafta, and most of his many teachings are stated in the name of his father. He was a friend and study partner of R. Yehudah haNasi. At one point, he controversially worked for the Roman government catching thieves.
description.he: רבי ישמעאל למד אצל אביו, רבי יוסי בן חלפתא, ורוב האמרות שלו מובאות בשם אביו. למד עם רבי יהודה הנשיא. בתקופה מסוימת פעל באופן שנוי במחלקות כשסייע לשלטון הרומאי בלכידת גנבים.

description.en: Divine repayment.

enBio.value: Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag, also known as the Ba’al HaSulam, was a rabbi and kabbalist. Born in Poland, he emigrated to Israel in 1921 and was appointed rabbi of Givat Shaul, Jerusalem. He is best known for his work Talmud Eser Sefirot, a commentary on the work of Isaac Luria, as well as HaSulam, a commentary on the Zohar. While kabbalah was traditionally treated as a body of secrets reserved for elite students, Ashlag believed it held the keys to finding meaning and achieving personal and social reform, and should be made accessible to all. He and his students were instrumental in the contemporary popularization of kabbalah study.

description.en: Moab’s residents were descended from Lot, and the Torah commands the Israelites to neither attack nor absorb the Moabites. Notably, King David is descended from a Moabite, the convert Ruth. Moab was located in modern-day Jordan.

description.en: Torah study involves the study of sacred Jewish texts, like the Torah, Mishnah, Talmud, and works of midrash, kabbalah, and Jewish thought. It is considered central to religious practice, with blessings acknowledging the commandment to engage in Torah study and thanking God for giving the Torah featured at the beginning of daily liturgy. The subject, form, and nature of Torah study vary between individuals and communities.
description.he: לימוד תורה הוא חלק אינטגרלי מהמסורת היהודית. הוא כרוך בלימוד הטקסטים היהודיים, לרבות תנ״ך, משנה, תלמוד, ספרי קבלה ומחשבת ישראל, ועוד. לימוד התורה נחשב למצווה ומוערך מאוד בתרבות היהודית כאמצעי לחיבור עם האל, להעמקת הידע וההבנה של האדם ולשיפור התנהגותו המוסרית והאתית. מקור המצווה  הוא במספר פסוקים בספר דברים: ״וְלִמַּדְתֶּם אֹתָם אֶת בְּנֵיכֶם לְדַבֵּר בָּם בְּשִׁבְתְּךָ בְּבֵיתֶךָ וּבְלֶכְתְּךָ בַדֶּרֶךְ וּבְשָׁכְבְּךָ וּבְקוּמֶךָ״ (דברים, יא, יט), ״וּלְמַדְתֶּם אֹתָם וּשְׁמַרְתֶּם לַעֲשֹׂתָם״ (דברים, ה, א), ״וְשִׁנַּנְתָּם לְבָנֶיךָ וְדִבַּרְתָּ בָּם״ (דברים, ו, ז).

description.en: In Judaism, priests are believed to be the descendants of [Aaron](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/aaron?tab=sources). In the Bible, they are charged with doing the ritual work in the [Mishkan](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mishkan?tab=sources) and later the Temples, under the leadership of a [high priest](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/high-priest?tab=sources). In Temple times, priests were also entitled to certain gifts and portions of sacrifices. Today, some people of priestly descent recite a special blessing in the synagogue and are careful to avoid contact with corpses, among other responsibilities and restrictions. The Hebrew word for priest is kohen.

description.en: *Avodat Hashem* — ”service of God” in English — is a primary religious objective in many Jewish texts. The first use of the term “service” in relationship to people serving God is in the book of Exodus, describing the expected [worship](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.7.16?lang=he&with=all&lang2=he) of the Israelites upon leaving Egypt. In later Jewish sources, *avodat Hashem* takes the form of ritual sacrifices, prayer, general fulfillment of the Torah’s commandments, or ethical character development.

description.en: Sukkot is a weeklong celebration of the harvest in early fall. It is celebrated by the building of temporary booths — that is, sukkot — outside homes in which people eat their meals and sometimes even sleep. The booths are reminders of the transience of life and the sheltering presence of God.
description.he: חג הסוכות, הוא חג האסיף, נמשך שבעה ימים ומצוין בחודש תשרי על-ידי בניית סוכה מחוץ לבית, בה  אוכלים וחלק גם ישנים. הסוכה היא תזכורת לסוכות שבנו בני ישראל ביציאת מצרים, ומסמלת את ארעיות החיים ואת נוכחותו המגוננת של ה'

description.en: Any [level](/topics/level) of reality that incorporates another [level](/topics/level) within it is called the external clothing of the inner [level](/topics/level), and the inner [level](/topics/level) is enclothed within that outer [level](/topics/level). For example, a vessel that contains the light is also the clothing of the light and the light is enclothed within it. Likewise, the body is described as clothing for the soul.

The [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Tiferet* is the sixth of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). When the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are divided into the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), *Tiferet*, and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) –*Tiferet* is parallel to the third [level](/topics/level) of the direct light of giving emanating from the Creator. This [level](/topics/level) of light is primarily drawn from the desire of the created beings to bond with the Creator, a will to give, but it also contains a certain amount of the will to receive the light of the Creator, which draws in illuminations from the light of wisdom.  *Tiferet* means “Beauty” (the concept of harmony), and it is called by this name because it is able to integrate both kinds of light within it, the light of wisdom, and the light of giving. This integration, which can be thought of as being formed of two columns of light, as well as an intermediating column which connects them, is the harmonious beauty of this *sefira*. It is this integrative capacity and its unique combination of lights that gives *Tiferet* its unique characterization in which the five *sefirot* that comprise it are given different names (recall that each *sefira* is formed of all five *sefirot*): The [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) in *Tiferet* is called [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed). The [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) in *Tiferet* is called [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura). The [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) in *Tiferet* is called *Tiferet*. The *Tiferet* within *Tiferet* is called *Netzaḥ*. The [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) within *Tiferet* is called [*Hod*](/topics/hod1). In addition to these five, there is a sixth [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) in *Tiferet* called [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), which includes the preceding five within it. It is this grouping of the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) that gives rise to the familiar count of ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot).  In the structure of [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), *Tiferet* is considered the [body](/topics/body3) of the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1). Two hands ([*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed) and [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura)) emerge from the [body](/topics/body3), as well as two legs ([*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1)) and the limb of procreation and life ([*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1)), thus forming the image of the human body. The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) that correlates to *Tiferet* is [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1), which encompasses the [*six extremities*](/topics/six-extremities). Each of the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) is also parallel to one of the five worlds that form existence. The world that correlates to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Tiferet* is the world of [*Yetzira*](/topics/yetzira1).
description.he: ​​ספירת התפארת היא הספירה הרביעית לפי החלוקה העיקרית של הספירות לחמש (כתר חכמה בינה תפארת ומלכות) והיא מקבילה לבחינה ג' של האור הישר, הוא 'אור חסדים בהארת החכמה', כלומר עיקרו אור החסדים (הנמשך מרצון הנבראים להידבק בבורא) של הבינה, אך מתעורר בו גם רצון מסוים לקבל את אור הבורא, והוא מושך חלק מאור החכמה, האור העליון.

description.en: Pinchas was a priest best known for his violent reaction to Israelite worship of the god Ba'al Pe'or. As this worship was associated with sexual relationships between Israelite men and Moabite and Midianite women, he killed one such couple mid-intercourse. Pinchas was a leader of the Israelites when they went into the Promised Land.
description.he: פינחס נודע בעיקר בשל תגובתו האלימה נגד המשתחווים לבעל פעור. פולחן בעל פעור היה כרוך במגע מיני בין גברים מבני ישראל ונשים מואביות ומדייניות, ופינחס הרג זוג כזה בשעת מעשה. הוא היה מבכירי ההנהגה של עם ישראל בכניסתם לארץ המובטחת.

description.en: The *sefirot* represent ten ways through which the Creator reveals Himself in the creation, with each *sefira* representing a different degree of revelation. The term *sefira* itself has the same root as the word sapir, which means sapphire or radiance, indicating that the divine light is contained within the *sefirot* and illuminates the creation through them.  Generally, there are ten *sefirot*: [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). But in essence there are five primary *sefirot*: [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). Additionally, each of these five *sefirot* are themselves composed of the other *sefirot*, since everything in reality is formed out of *sefirot*. Thus, for example, the *sefira* of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) contains the [levels](/topics/level) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1).  As for the five remaining *sefirot*, [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1), they are encompassed within the *sefira* of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). Like the other *sefirot*, the *sefira* of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) contains all five *sefirot*, but in this case they are called by different names: In this context, they are called [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1). The reason the sefirot are given different names is that a different kind of light from that of the other *sefirot*, called the “light of giving,” is revealed through [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). Although they are named differently, they are still, in a sense, the same five *sefirot* mentioned above. Thus, [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed) is referred to as the [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura) as the [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) as the [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah) as the [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Hod*](/topics/hod1) as the [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). In addition to these five, there is another *sefira* that incorporates all the [levels](/topics/level) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) called [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1).

description.en: Shemittah, or the sabbatical year, is the seventh year of the seven-year agricultural cycle mandated by the Torah in the land of Israel. During the Shemittah year, working the land is prohibited, produce that grows on the land takes on sacred status, and debts are forgiven. Shemittah is first mentioned in the Torah in [Exodus 23:10-11](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.23.10?ven=The_Contemporary_Torah,_Jewish_Publication_Society,_2006&lang=he&with=all&lang2=he).

description.en: In the Jewish textual tradition, exile (*galut* in Hebrew) is viewed as both a punishment and a way to make amends with God. The tension between exile from and return to Israel is a common theme in Jewish literature — from Abraham's exile to Egypt to the modern return of Jews to the state of Israel.
description.he: עבור העם היהודי הגלות נושאת עימה משמעות כפולה – הן של עונש על חטאים והן של כפרה עליהם. המתח שבין הגלות ובין השיבה אל ארץ ישראל הוא מאפיין שכיח בספרות היהודית, החל בירידתו של אברהם למצרים וכלה בשיבת היהודים אל מדינת ישראל של ימינו.

description.en: In the Bible, the Hebrew word for "wisdom," *chokhmah,* can take on different meanings depending on context: for example, the word can refer to superior intellect, moral discernment, or excellence with a practical skill. Several biblical characters are described as wise, from [Betzalel](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/betzalel?tab=admin) to the [wise woman from Tekoa](https://www.sefaria.org/II_Samuel.14.2?ven=english|Tanakh:_The_Holy_Scriptures,_published_by_JPS&lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) to, perhaps most notably, [King Solomon](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/king-solomon?tab=admin). Later Jewish texts further explore the nature, divine origins, merits, and limitations of wisdom.

description.en: Nebuchadnezzar (prounounced in Hebrew, Nevukhadnetzar) was a Babylonian king who exiled many Judeans, including their then-king Jehoiachin, in 597 BCE and then in 586 BCE conquered Judah and destroyed Jerusalem and [the First Temple](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/destruction-of-the-temple?tab=sources). The book of Daniel describes him as later recognizing God's power and going mad.
description.he: נבוכדנצר הוא ממלכי בבל. הוא כבש את ירושלים והגלה את תושביה לבבל. בספר דניאל מתואר שבתקופה מאוחרת יותר הכיר נבוכדנצר בגדולת אלוהי ישראל ואיבד את שפיותו.

image_caption.he: Nebuchadnezzar before the fiery furnace (Daniel 3:26), Hartwell James 1905, 1916 {PD-US}

description.en: There were two Jewish Temples, or *battei mikdash* (singular: *beit mikdash*) that stood in ancient Jerusalem. The first was built by [King Solomon](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/king-solomon?tab=admin) and destroyed by the Babylonians in 586 BCE, and the second was built in the late sixth century BCE with the blessing of the Persian Empire and was later destroyed by the Romans in 70 CE. These Temples were the central site of Jewish sacrifice and pilgrimage while they stood. The destruction of these holy Temples was tragic, traumatic, and completely transformational for Jews and Judaism. The Temples and the service of God that took place there are described extensively in Jewish texts, as are their destructions and practices surrounding how they are mourned to this very day.
description.he: בית המקדש נבנה בירושלים בידי שלמה המלך כדי להחליף את המשכן ואת המזבחות האחרים בארץ וכדי לשמש מרכז לחיים היהודיים ולעבודת הפולחן היהודית. החורבן הסופי של המקדש מתואר באריכות במקורות חז"ל.

image_caption.he: An illustration of Beit Hamikdash, Leipnik Haggadah.,1740. From the British Library archive

description.en: A variation of the term "evil inclination" – *yetzer hara* in Hebrew – is first found in the book of [Genesis](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.6.5?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en), as God acknowledges the evil impulse within people. In rabbinic literature, the evil inclination is often discussed in contrast to its opposite, the good inclination (*yetzer hatov* in Hebrew). In some sources, the force is presented as an internal drive within people, while other texts depict the *yetzer hara* as an external figure that can tempt people toward bad choices.

The word Shekhinah, referring to God's imminent presence, comes from the Hebrew root for "dwell." In rabbinic literature, the Shekhinah represents a protective presence that can rest among the people; in Lurianic Kabbalah, “Shekhinah” refers to the feminine aspect of God and carries particular significance in unifying God’s presence in the world. In both rabbinic and kabbalistic literature, the Shekhinah joins the people of Israel in exile, and humans have a role in bringing the presence of God closer or pushing God’s presence further away.

Daniel is the protagonist of the Book of Daniel. He was taken to the court of Nevukhadnetsar after he conquered Jerusalem. There he rose in the court but prophecied the destruction of Babylonia by Persia. He later had visions regarding the coming Macedonian and Seleucid Greek empires.
description.he: דניאל הוא הגיבור של ספר דניאל המקראי. לאחר כיבוש ירושלים וחורבן העיר על ידי הבבלים הוא נלקח לחצר נבוכדנצר מלך בבל. הוא גדל בבית המלך אך נותר נאמן לאמונתו. הוא ניבא את חורבן בבל על ידי ממלכת פרס ואת עליית האימפריה המקדוני והסלאוקי.

image_caption.he: Daniel at Belshazzar's feast, England [N.W. Midlands]; circa 1375-1400

description.en: Mashiach (the Messiah) — literally "anointed one" — generally refers to a savior or liberator figure believed to be a future redeemer of Jews, who ushers in the messianic era. Generations of Jewish texts debate what the messianic era entails, as well as the role that belief in the Messiah should play in Jewish practice. In the Bible, the word *mashiach* is used to refer to kings or high priests, selected by God and anointed with oil.
description.he: משיח - דמות מרכזית בשליחות אלוהים, הנחשבת כגואלת העתידית של עם ישראל, פותחת את העידן המשיחי ומביאה לבסוף לשלום עולמי. מקורות היהדות לאורך הדורות מתווכחים על אופיים של ימות המשיח ועל התפקיד שהאמונה במשיח צריכה למלא. כל המקורות שותפים לציפייה למשיח ולגאולה שמלווה את העם היהודי דורות רבים ומוזכרת פעמים רבות בתפילה ובשאר המקורות. בתנ"ך, המילה *משיח* משמשת להתייחסות למלכים או כוהנים גדולים, שנבחרו על ידי אלוהים ונמשחו בשמן.

description.en: The book of [Exodus](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus?tab=contents) recounts how, after hundreds of years of the Israelites' slavery in Egypt, God miraculously frees the people through a process of [ten plagues](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-ten-plagues?tab=admin) and the splitting of the [Red Sea](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/splitting-of-the-red-sea?tab=admin). The [Passover](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/passover?tab=admin) holiday commemorates these events, and discussing the Exodus is a focal point of the Passover [seder](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/seder?tab=admin).
description.he: יציאת מצרים היא סיפור המתואר בספר שמות בתנ״ך, שבמהלכו יצאו בני ישראל באופן ניסי משעבודו של העם המצרי. הניסים המרכזיים המתוארים בסיפור הם עשרת המכות ששיאם במכת בכורות, וקריעת ים סוף אשר אפשרה לעם ישראל לברוח מהצבא המצרי לכיוון ארץ כנען. חג הפסח מהווה זיכרון ליציאת מצרים, וההגדה של פסח, אשר אותה קוראים בליל הסדר, דנה בהשתלשלות האירועים.

image_caption.he: קריעת ים סוף, פרסקו מבית הכנסת דורא אירופוס, 244-256.

description.en: Ezekiel was a prophet in the time of the kings Josiah and Jehoiachin who had mystical visions about God's chariot, majesty, and hosts. According to Jewish tradition, accounts of his visions were later written down to make up the book of Ezekiel.
description.he: יחזקאל הוא נביא בתקופת המלכים יאשיהו ויהויכין. נבואותיו מתאפיינות בחזיונות בעלי משמעות מיסטית של מרכבת האל, מלוכתו וצבאותיו. על פי המסורת היהודית, נבואותיו נכתבו כספר בתקופה מאוחרת יותר.

description.en: Korach was a Levite who rebelled against Moses's authority. He, his fellow rebels, and their families were all swallowed up by the earth.
description.he: קֹרַח הוא בן שבט לוי שמרד בסמכותו של משה. הוא וְיתר המורדים שהצטרפו אליו קיפחו את חייהם – חלקם נשרפו למוות ואת חלקם בלעה האדמה עם בני משפחותיהם.

description.en: Often translated as bounty, flow, or abundance, *shefa* comes from the Hebrew word *hashpa’a*, which in this context means to give. Rays of sunlight, for example, can be described as the sun’s *shefa*. The rays constitute a “flow” of light from the sun that provides light and sustenance to the earth in bountiful abundance. In kabbalistic thought, *shefa* refers to different forms of light that flow from God's essence or from the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) and the like. Additionally, *shefa* can be used to refer both to God’s giving to creation, as well as the giving of created beings to each other.

description.en: Ahab was the seventh king of the northern Kingdom of Israel, and a wicked one. He allowed foreign worship to flourish under his wife Jezebel's influence, and was willing to arbitrarily dispossess his subjects. He was eventually killed in a military campaign against the Arameans.
description.he: אחאב, המלך השביעי בממלכת ישראל, היה מלך רשע. תחת השפעתה של איזבל אשתו התיר ועודד פריחה של עבודה זרה בתקופתו והסכים לנשל את נתיניו מאדמותיהם באופן שרירותי. נהרג במערכה צבאית נגד הארמים.

description.en: Elisha was a prophet in the Book of Kings and the successor of Elijah (Eliyahu). He was known as a miracle worker, performing such feats as resurrecting the dead and healing the sick. He also aided and saved the life of the Israelite king Jehoash.
description.he: אלישע היה נביא בספר מלכים ויורשו של אליהו. נודע בתור עושה ניסים, למשל החיה נער מת וריפא חולים. הוא גם סייע ליואש מלך ישראל והציל את חייו.

description.en: Ishmael was the first son of Abraham, by his concubine Hagar. Acting on Sarah's advice and God's instruction, he and his mother were expelled from their home. An angel reassured them and showed them where to find water and he became the ancestor of the Ishmaelites.
description.he: ישמעאל הוא בנו הבכור של אברהם ובנה של הגר פילגשו. בעקבות עצת שרה וצו האל שולחו ישמעאל והגר מבית אברהם. לאחר שנקלעו למצוקה במדבר, נגלה אליהם מלאך שהוביל אותם לבאר מים ועודד אותם בנוגע לעתידם. ישמעאל הוא אבי העם הישמעאלי.

image_caption.he: Abraham banishes Hagar and Ishmael; Sarah and Isaac look on. Gerard Hoet (1648–1733)

description.en: Jewish texts approach joy in a number of ways — from the Torah's commanding of Jews to rejoice in certain contexts to joy's characterization as a divine response to humanity's fulfillment of God's will. While joy itself can be a form of serving God, in some instances it can also be a human response to divine action or of being close to God.
description.he: השמחה פרושה לאורך מקורות היהדות כנקודת מוצא חיובית ומומלצת. עם זאת ישנה ביקורת כנגד "שמחת הוללות". לעתים, השמחה עצמה מתוארת כדרך לעבודת השם ולהשגת קרבת אלוהים. בהקשרים מסוימים התורה מצווה לשמוח.

description.en: Animals are present from the very beginning of the Torah, as they are among God's first creations in the [book of Genesis](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis?tab=contents). Animals feature in a variety of contexts, such as biblical and talmudic stories, legal discussions about how to treat them, and poetic liturgical works that marvel at their wonders.

description.en: [The Shema](https://www.sefaria.org/Siddur_Ashkenaz%2C_Weekday%2C_Shacharit%2C_Blessings_of_the_Shema%2C_Shema?lang=bi), Judaism's most famous prayer, is actually not a prayer at all. Rather it is a declaration of God's unity and other central doctrines of Judaism. It involves reciting three passages from the Torah, one of which is interrupted by another ancient phrase, the origins of which are outside the Bible.
description.he: קריאת שמע היא תפילה ידועה השגורה בפי עם ישראל והיא כוללת שלושה קטעים מפסוקי התורה ומשפט אחד שאינו מן התנ"ך. המילים של קריאת שמע הן הצהרה על ייחוד האל, אהבתו וקבלת עול מצוות. קריאת שמע היא מצווה מהתורה הנאמרת פעמיים ביום, בתפילת שחרית ובתפילת ערבית. רבים שמתו על קידוש השם קראו את קריאת שמע לפני מותם כהצהרה על אמונתם.

description.en: Elazar was a son of Aaron who succeeded him in the role of the high priest. He continued his role in the land of Israel and assisted Joshua in the partitioning of the land among tribes and families.
description.he: אלעזר, בנו של אהרן הכהן, ירש את מקומו ככוהן גדול. הוא המשיך בתפקיד זה אחרי הכניסה לארץ ישראל ויחד עם יהושע חילק את הארץ לשבטים ולמשפחות.

description.en: Faith is a value central to Judaism. The biblical [Abraham](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/abraham?sort=Relevance&tab=notable-sources) is noted throughout Jewish texts as a paradigm of fatih. Medieval scholars like Maimonides crafted principles of faith, and sources throughout the Jewish tradition tell stories of faith and discuss the role and nature of faith in Judaism.

description.en: Isaiah, to whom the book of Isaiah is traditionally attributed, is one of the major biblical prophets. He is known for both prophesying the doom of Israel and its redemption — both politically and in a messianic age.
description.he: ישעיהו הוא אחד הנביאים החשובים במקרא, ומקובל לייחס לו את ספר ישעיהו. הוא נודע בזכות נבואות החורבן והגאולה שלו. נבואותיו משלבות מרכיבים פוליטיים ומשיחיים.

description.en: There are assorted fast days scattered across the Jewish calendar. During the two major fast days, Yom Kippur and Tisha B'Av, one abstains from food, drink, washing, and sexual relations for 25 hours. During the other, minor fast days, one abstains from food and drink from sunup to sundown.

description.en: Samson was a judge, Nazirite and military leader in the book of Judges. After victories against the Philistines, he was tricked by his lover, Delilah, into betraying the source of his strength. He was captured and blinded by the Philistines, but he was eventually able to kill many of them, and himself, by destroying their temple.
description.he: שמשון היה שופט, נזיר ומנהיג צבאי בספר שופטים. אחרי שהוביל כמה ניצחונות על הפלישתים, הצליחה דלילה, המאהבת שלו, להערים עליו ולגלות את מקור כוחו. הוא נשבה על ידי הפלישתים שעיוורו את עיניו, אך הצליח להרוג את שוביו ופלישתים רבים אחרים והתאבד כשהחריב את מקדשם.

description.en: Many biblical characters are described as loving their spouses or children. The Torah commands people to love in specific contexts – like loving one’s fellow, the stranger, and God – and [Song of Songs](https://www.sefaria.org/Song_of_Songs?tab=contents) consists of poetic conversations between two lovers. Jewish texts composed over thousands of years explore the wonders, hardships, and practical manifestations of love.
description.he: דמויות מקראיות רבות מתוארות כאוהבות את בני זוגן או ילדיהן. התורה מצווה על אנשים לאהוב בהקשרים ספציפיים - כמו אהבת הזולת, הגר והאל וגם פרקי מגילת שיר השירים הם למעשה שיח של שירה בין שני אוהבים. מקורות יהדות שנכתבו לאורך הדורות עוסקים בביטויים המעשיים של אהבה וגם בקשיים שבה.

description.en: Neshama

Egypt (Mitzrayim) plays a central role in the Bible, named both as a land of refuge and a land of danger and subjugation, particularly in the Passover narrative. Egypt is complex, both as the birthplace of the Jewish nation and as the one place the Torah tells Jews not to live. Despite this, Jewish communities flourished in Egypt from antiquity until relatively recently.
description.he: למצרים תפקיד חשוב בתנ"ך, והיא מוזכרת בו גם כמקום מפלט וגם כארץ של סכנה ושעבוד, בייחוד בסיפור יציאת מצרים. עבור היהודים מצרים היא תסביך – מצד אחד זהו מקום לידתו של העם היהודי, ומצד שני זהו המקום היחיד שנאסר עליו לגור בו.

description.en: Olam Haba–"the world to come" in English–is a phrase used to describe the afterlife, understood by some as the place where individual souls go upon death and by others as the place where bodies go, together with their souls, in a future time known as [*techiyat hametim*](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/resurrection?tab=admin) (revival of the dead). The world to come is not explicitly mentioned in the Bible, but later sources understand it as a place where divine justice is executed.

description.en: Ruth is the protagonist of the [book of Ruth](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-book-of-ruth?tab=sources). Though a Moabite foreigner, she followed her beloved Israelite mother-in-law Naomi to Bethlehem after their husbands died. She committed herself to Naomi and to her God and to the nation of Israel. She marries her late husband's next of kin, and their child was an ancestor of King David.
description.he: רות היא גיבורת מגילת רות. אף שהייתה מואבייה נוכרייה, הלכה אחרי חמותה העברייה נעמי וליוותה אותה בשובה לבית לחם לאחר ששתיהן שכלו את בעליהן. רות התמסרה לנעמי ולעם היהודי. בארץ נישאה לבועז, והמלך דוד היה אחד מצאצאיהם.

description.en: Ovyut denotes thickness, materiality, or darkness, as opposed to purity, clarity, and spirituality. In kabbalistic terminology, it expresses the quality of the vessel, which is the will to receive. It is considered thick and dark because it is the antithesis of the eternal divine light, the essence of which is entirely giving. A greater will to receive is regarded as having greater opacity, while a vessel that contains a lesser will to receive is regarded as being more pure. This is because the greater the will to receive that a vessel acquires, the more it is distanced from the Creator and His light and the more material and dark it becomes.

*Keter* is the name of the first and highest [sefira](/topics/sefira2) of the ten [sefirot](/topics/sefirot). However, *Keter* is not always counted as one of the ten [sefirot](/topics/sefirot). Just as a crown, a *keter*, on a person’s head encompasses him but is not part of his body, so too the [sefira](/topics/sefira2) of *Keter*, due to its lofty status, can be considered above the ten [sefirot](/topics/sefirot). When *Keter* is regarded as part of the system, it is the highest part of the [head](/topics/head2), which is comprised of the first three [levels](/topics/level): *Keter*, [Ḥokhma](/topics/hokhma1), and [*Bina*](/topics/bina3). When *Keter* is not included in the list of [sefirot](/topics/sefirot), it is substituted by *Da’at*, a structure that can be considered a pseudo-*sefira*.

The [book of Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/Esther) is one of the five megillot (scrolls), part of the section of the Hebrew Bible called Writings. It tells the story of [Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/esther), a Jew who becomes queen of Persia and together with her cousin, [Mordekhai](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mordekhai), foils a plot of the evil [Haman](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/haman) to destroy the Jews. To commemorate the transformation from “grief and mourning to festive joy” (9:22), Esther and Mordekhai establish the holiday of [Purim](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/purim). The book of Esther is read publicly in the evening and morning of Purim.

description.en: Rachel is one of the four matriarchs of the Jewish people. The beloved and favored wife of [Jacob](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/jacob?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), who was tricked into first marrying her older sister [Leah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/leah?tab=sources), Rachel suffered from infertility before giving birth to Jacob's two favored sons, Joseph and Benjamin. She died giving birth to Benjamin.
description.he: רחל היא אחת מארבע האימהות של עם ישראל. היא אשתו האהובה והבכירה של יעקב, שנישא קודם לכן לאחותה לאה. רחל סבלה מעקרות ממושכת לפני שילדה את שני בניו הצעירים והאהובים ביותר של יעקב, יוסף ובנימין. היא מתה בשעת לידתו של בנימין.

description.en: Miracles feature throughout the Jewish textual tradition. Supernatural events appear throughout the Bible, including the [ten plagues](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-ten-plagues?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), the [splitting of the sea](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/splitting-of-the-red-sea?tab=sources), and when the walls of [Jericho](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/jericho?tab=sources) fell, among others. Miracles feature in later rabbinic texts as well, and ancient through contemporary works analyze the nature and significance of miracles.
description.he: ניסים מופיעים לאורך כל מסורת ההספרות היהודית. אירועים על-טבעיים מופיעים לאורך התנ"ך, כמו עשר המכות, קריעת ים סוף ונפילת חומות יריחו . ניסים מופיעים גם במקורות יהדות מימי המשנה והתלמוד, ואף בחיבורים מאוחרים יותר.מקורות רבים עוסקים בתפקידו של הנס ומשמעותו.

description.en: Mar Ukva was among the first of the exilarchs - administrative leaders of the Jewish community in Babylonia who claimed descent from the House of David. He was an important judge and scholar and a student of Shmuel. Known for his piety and wealth, he was famous for his discretion and generosity.
description.he: מר עוקבא היה מראשוני "ראשי הגולה"– המנהיגים האדמיניסטרטיביים של הקהילה היהודית בבבל שטענו שהם צאצאי בית דוד. הוא היה שופט חשוב, חכם גדול ותלמיד של שמואל. נודע בחסידותו ובעושרו וכן בהקפדתו לתת צדקה בסתר.

description.en: Jerusalem — Yerushalayim in Hebrew — is considered the holiest city in the Jewish textual tradition. Although it is not mentioned explicitly in the Torah, the book of Deuteronomy refers numerous times to "the place that God will choose," a phrase later sources understood to refer to Jerusalem. In the book of Samuel, [King David](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/king-david?tab=sources) captured Jerusalem from the Jebusites, and the book of Kings recounts that [King Solomon](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/king-solomon?tab=sources) built the Temple there. Jerusalem is a central focus of many Jewish prayers, customs, and texts.

description.en: Yom Tov (literally: "good day") refers to any Jewish holiday marked by ritual blessings over the wine and abstention from work: the beginning and end of Passover, Shavuot, Rosh HaShanah, Yom Kippur, the beginning and end of Sukkot, Shemini Atseret, and Simchat Torah.

description.en: The Hebrew word for "peace," *shalom,* is related to the Hebrew word that means whole or perfect, *shalem.* This suggests that there is a relationship between peace and wholeness. Judaism values peace very highly, prioritizing it over nearly everything else, as is reflected in biblical, rabbinic, liturgical, ethical, and legal texts.
description.he: שלום הוא ערך מרכזי בתפיסת העולם היהודית ומופיע במגוון הקשרים במקורות היהדות. ברכת השלום חותמת את תפילת העמידה, את תפילת הקדיש והמילה "שלום" היא אחת משמותיו של האל. בספרי היהדות לאורך הדורות השלום נתפס כמצב אידיאלי והרמוני כאשר המחלוקת לגביו היא כיצד ניתן להשיגו, עד כמה נכון לוותר ולהתפשר עבורו וכיצד להכריע כאשר יש קונפליקט בין האמת והשלום.

description.en: Tzara'at is a biblical disease that involved discoloration of one's skin, home, or clothing. Once confirmed by a priest's inspection, it renders the subject ritually impure, requiring them to leave the camp for a period, undergo further inspection, and then a purification process. Tzara'at is the subject of [Leviticus 13–14](https://www.sefaria.org/Leviticus.13?lang=bi&aliyot=0). Several biblical stories have characters inflicted with tzara'at. And tzara'at is the subject of the Mishnah's tractate [Negaim](https://www.sefaria.org/Mishnah_Negaim?tab=contents).

description.en: The [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Yesod* is the ninth of the ten [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot). When the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are divided into the five primary [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) – [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), [*Bina*](/topics/bina3), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), and [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) – *Yesod* is encompassed in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1).  *Yesod* is the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) that represents the end of the middle line or column, the line of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). Accordingly, *Yesod* is a unique aspect of the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) and also exists in parallel in the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1), which receives the lights of [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1). *Yesod*, which means “Foundation,” is named thus because it includes the “foundations” of its [level](/topics/level), meaning the various lights within that [level](/topics/level). It then transmits these lights to the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) below it, so that *Yesod* serve as the foundation for the existence of the feminine aspect of the [level](/topics/level). In the structure of [*partzufim*](/topics/partzuf), which correlate to the human body, the [*sefira*](/topics/sefira2) of *Yesod* represents the sexual reproductive organs.

The [Mishnah](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Mishnah) is the first major work of rabbinic literature, consisting of teachings transmitted over hundreds of years and compiled around 200 CE. It covers agricultural, ritual, civil, criminal, and Temple-related laws, presenting a multiplicity of legal opinions and incorporating occasional stories. It is a foundation of the Jewish oral tradition, which continues with the [Talmud](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Talmud/Bavli), a work that is structured as commentary on the Mishnah.

description.en: Treating others with kindness is a foundational Jewish practice and is considered one of [three pillars on which the world stands](https://www.sefaria.org/Pirkei_Avot.1.2?lang=bi). Biblical characters like Abraham exemplify kindness in their generous treatment of strangers, and [rabbinic texts](https://www.sefaria.org/Sotah.14a.4?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) instruct people to follow God’s example of behaving with kindness.

description.en: The haggadah is the classic ritual text that serves as the base and script of the Passover seder. Its text was compiled during the periods of the Mishnah and the Talmud, with later medieval additions. It is the most printed Jewish book as new editions and new commentaries are published every year. Different communities around the world have also developed their own variations and ritual practices, often recorded in the editions produced in their own communities.
description.he: ההגדה היא טקסט יהודי קלאסי המהווה את הבסיס לליל הסדר. רובה של ההגדה נכתבה במהלך תקופת המשנה והתלמוד. כיום, ההגדה קיימת בנוסחים רבים בקהילות שונות אשר הוסיפו להגדה פיוטים ותפילות שונות במרוצת הדורות. ההגדה מחולקת ל-14 חלקים אשר המרכזים בהם הינם: קדש - קידוש היום, מגיד - רוב המלל שבהגדה המתאר את סיפור יציאת מצרים, מוציא מצה והלל.

description.en: Wine (yayin) is widely discussed in Biblical and Rabbinic sources, with the focus being on its enjoyment as well as its potential for abuse. On Shabbat — and Jewish holidays — special prayers are said over wine in order to fulfill the Biblical commandment of sanctifying the day.

description.en: Tisha B’Av, the ninth day of the Hebrew month of Av, is a fast day and the saddest day on the Jewish calendar. Among other historical tragedies, it commemorates the destruction of the First and Second Temples in Jerusalem in 586 BCE and 70 CE, respectively. One fasting abstains from food and other physical pleasures, reads the biblical book of Lamentations, and observes mourning customs.
description.he: תשעה באב, החל בט' באב, הוא צום בן 25 שעות שיוצא בדרך כלל ביולי או אוגוסט. יום זה, המצוין על-ידי הימנעות מאכילה, שתייה, רחצה, יחסי מין ומלבושי עור, הוא יום של אבל על חורבן בית המקדש הראשון והשני בירושלים.

description.en: The light of giving (*or ḥassadim*) is the type of [*shefa*](/topics/shefa1)  that is revealed as a result of the will or desire of a created being to give. This light originates in the second [level](/topics/level) of the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), the [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3). This is in contrast to the other type of [*shefa*](/topics/shefa1), the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1), which is the light of the Creator that emanates in and from the first [level](/topics/level) of the [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot), the [level](/topics/level) of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). Although the light of giving is not the main lifeforce of the created beings, it contains an important quality related to the [constriction](/topics/constriction) (*tzimtzum*). Constriction involves the abstention of the vessel of the will to receive (the vessel of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1)) from receiving the light of the Creator. However, this [constriction](/topics/constriction) of the vessel applies only to the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1). The receiving vessel for the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is the will of the created being to receive. After the [constriction](/topics/constriction) this vessel is disqualified as a vessel for the divine light. However, [constriction](/topics/constriction) does not apply to the light of giving, whose vessel is the will of the created being to give. One result of this difference in the effects of the [constriction](/topics/constriction) is that the light of giving illuminates in places and ways where the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) does not shine. Additionally, by [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) in the light of giving, the light of giving helps the light of [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) illuminate [levels](/topics/level) from which it would otherwise be restricted.

The head refers to the highest part of a [level](/topics/level). For example, in each [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1), the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) are considered the head of that [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1). Additionally, the root of every [level](/topics/level) may also be defined as its head. This might occur when the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) resulting from a [*fusion through collision*](/topics/fusion-through-collision) with a [partition](/topics/partition2) [enclothed](/topics/enclothe) the supernal light. While this process ultimately allows for the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) to serve as a complete vessel for the supernal light, initially it only serves as the conceptual root of that actualized vessel. This initial stage of [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the supernal light by the [returning light](/topics/returning-light1) is called the head of the particular [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1).

Shortly after the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, despairing that their leader Moses had died atop the mountain, the Israelites built and began to worship a golden calf — in direct violation of the first commandments of the [Ten Commandments](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.20.3?lang=bi&aliyot=0). The "golden calf" may refer to either the idol the Israelites built or [the narrative](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.32?lang=bi&aliyot=0). Upon Moses' discovery of the Israelites' grievous transgression, he smashed the tablets of the law, ground up the golden calf, and made the Israelites drink the mixture.

Tefillin are black leather boxes that contain small parchment scrolls on which specific passages from the Torah are written. Tefillin are worn on the upper arm and forehead, usually during morning prayers, except on Shabbat and holidays, as the means of fulfilling the commandment to "bind them as a sign on your hand and as a symbol between your eyes" [(Deuteronomy 6:8)](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.6.8?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en).
description.he: תפילין הן קופסות עור שחורות ובתוכן מגילות קלף של פסוקים מן התורה. יהודים מגיל בר מצווה מניחים את התפילין על הזרוע ועל המצח מדי יום חול לפחות פעם אחת ביום החל בתפילת שחרית.

description.en: A neder is a vow taken voluntarily. A vow can forbid one from deriving pleasure from particular objects or actions, obligate one to perform an action in the future, or declare that an individual is becoming a [Nazirite](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/nazir?tab=sources), among other functions. Stories of vows feature throughout the Bible, and many laws relating to vows are derived from [Numbers 30](https://www.sefaria.org/Numbers.30.3?ven=The_Contemporary_Torah,_Jewish_Publication_Society,_2006&lang=en&aliyot=0).

description.en: Kashrut means “fitness” and refers to the dietary laws governing what is permitted and forbidden for consumption. These laws further prescribe how kosher food should be prepared and by whom. While the Torah dictates which animals may be consumed and under what conditions, the rabbis further derived principles to ensure that one does not violate the Torah and discuss the value of these practices.
description.he: "כשר" משמעו מתאים או ראוי. הכשרות היא סדרת הלכות מפורטות בענייני מזון – מה מותר ומה אסור לאכול, וכן כיצד יש להכין מאכלים שונים כדי שיהיו מותרים באכילה.

description.en: The Torah commands [“Justice, justice you shall pursue”](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.16.20?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) as a condition for inhabiting the land of Israel. The Torah further commands specific measures to be put in place in order to establish just societies, including just courts and fair and honest weights and measures. Several biblical prophets critique those who prioritize ritual practice but ignore the Torah’s imperatives to act justly, and sources throughout the rabbinic tradition discuss and analyze the requirements and parameters of justice.

description.en: Traditional Jewish sources [describe](https://www.sefaria.org/Megillah.14a.4?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) how 48 prophets and seven prophetesses prophesied on behalf of the people of Israel. Many of their teachings are recorded in the Prophets section of the Bible, which consists of collections of prophetic speeches and narrative accounts of history attributed to prophets. These prophets covered the period from the people of Israel's entrance into the land of Israel through the beginning of the Second Temple. In the Torah, [Abraham](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.20.8?lang=bi&aliyot=0) and [Moses](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.34.10?lang=bi&aliyot=0) are also called prophets, and the Torah warns against listening to a [false prophet](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.13.2?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en).

description.en: The Jewish tradition emphasizes that humility is a desirable character trait. This trait is exhibited by biblical characters — most notably [Moses](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/moses?tab=admin) — analyzed by commentators who discuss the balance between humility, self-worth, and self-recognition, and celebrated by works of musar that offer guidance on cultivating humility.

description.en: Time is a concept that appears from the very beginning of the Torah, as the world's creation unfolds over seven days, each of which is divided into evening and morning. Sources throughout the Jewish textual tradition discuss how God and people sanctify time, different ways of relating to the passing of time, how time governs the performance of commandments, and how to make the most of one's time.

description.en: Hannah is a biblical character from the book of Samuel who struggles with infertility. She visits the [Tabernacle](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/mishkan?tab=admin) and prays verbally for a child rather than simply offering a sacrifice. God takes note of her, and she gives birth to a son, the prophet Samuel, who would lead the Israelites. In Jewish tradition, Hannah becomes a model for verbal prayer and for audacity in beseeching God.
description.he: חנה היא אשת אלקנה ואם שמואל הנביא. היא התמודדה עם עקרות ממושכת, ובמצוקתה הגיעה למשכן בשילה. במקום להקריב קורבן בלבד היא נשאה תפילה בפה לילד, תפילה מילולית. האל שמע את תפילתה, והיא ילדה את שמואל, שבבגרותו היה לנביא ולמנהיג שהוביל את עם ישראל. על פי המסורת, חנה שימשה מודל לתפילה מילולית.

description.en: Ahasuerus was the king of Persia in the [book of Esther](https://www.sefaria.org/Esther?tab=contents). He agreed to his advisor Haman's plans to eradicate the Jews and confiscate their property, but his Jewish wife Esther and her cousin Mordekhai foiled the plot when Esther revealed her true identity as a Jew.
description.he: אחשוורוש הוא מלך פרס במגילת אסתר. הוא תמך בתוכניותיו של המן, הבכיר בשריו, להשמיד את כל היהודים במדינות מלכותו ולבזוז את רכושם, אך אסתר המלכה ובן דודהּ מרדכי סיכלו יחדיו את תוכניתו כאשר אסתר גילתה למלך את זהותה האמיתית, היהודית.

description.en: Yoav was King David's nephew and general, who led his forces against the rebellion of David's son Avshalom. After later joining the rebellion of David's son Adoniah, David ordered Solomon to kill him.
description.he: יואב היה האחיין של דוד המלך ושר צבאו. הוא הנהיג את כוחותיו של דוד נגד מרד בנו אבשלום. מאוחר יותר הצטרף יואב למרד של אדניה, גם הוא בנו של דוד, ובעקבות זאת הורה דוד לשלמה להוציאו להורג.

description.en: Evil speech — *lashon hara,* in Hebrew — refers to the prohibition against speech that is harmful to another person, even though it may be true. The parameters, laws, and spiritual implications of *lashon hara* are discussed throughout the Jewish textual tradition and are a focus of Rabbi Yisrael Meir Kagan's [Chafetz Chaim](https://www.sefaria.org/Chafetz_Chaim?tab=contents), the first work to organize the laws of proper speech comprehensively.
Zedekiah was the last king of Judah before it fell to the Babylonians. He was taken captive and brought to Babylon where he died.

description.en: Light, both physical and metaphorical, features prominently throughout the Jewish textual tradition. Among other instances, light is the first thing God creates in the book of Genesis, is a focus of the holiday of [Chanukkah](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/chanukkah?tab=sources), and is a central concept in kabbalastic literature, representing divine emanations.

description.en: Jewish texts have explored the concept of free will for thousands of years. A paradigmatic narrative through which the topic is often discussed is God’s [hardening of Pharoah’s heart](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/the-hardening-of-pharaohs-heart?sort=Relevance&tab=admin) in the Exodus narrative. Jewish thinkers analyze the interplay between free will and God’s omnipotence and consider the practical implications of free will in daily life.

Water features prominently from the opening chapter of the Torah, as God separates between the waters of the sky and the waters below. Water plays a role in many other biblical narratives, like the splitting of the Red Sea or the miraculous supply of water provided to the people of Israel in the desert. Later Jewish sources discuss water extensively, acknowledging its physical necessity as a life-sustaining element and spiritual significance, and delving into details about its usage in Temple rituals, as a metaphor for Torah, and more.

description.en: Amalek was the first nation to attack the Israelites in the desert, attacking them from behind so as to target the weak and weary stragglers. As a result of this, paradoxically, the Torah commands the Israelites simultaneously to remember what they did and to blot out even the memory of them.

description.en: The 12 spies feature in the books of Numbers and Deuteronomy. They were a group of leaders – one from each tribe – sent by Moses to scout the land of Canaan ahead of the people of Israel's arrival there. They came back reporting that the land was good but filled with giants and fearsome enemies. This prompted the Israelites to cry and complain that they did not want to enter the land. Two of the 12 spies, Joshua and Caleb, attempted to assuage their fears.

description.en: The shofar is made from the horn of an animal, usually a ram. In the Bible, the shofar was blown as a trumpet in battle and, today, is used primarily during Rosh Hashanah services and at the end of Yom Kippur as a “wake up call” to repentance or to announce God the King.

description.en:
The [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) of [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is called *Arikh Anpin*, or “the long face,” on account of the essence of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) within it. [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1) is called [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1), or “the small face,” because it contains only a slight illumination from the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma). The names *Arikh Anpin* and [*Ze’er Anpin*](/topics/zeer-anpin1) correspond to one another, for they refer only to the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) in the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1), since the [*Ḥokhma*](/topics/hokhma1) is called the [light](/topics/light2) of the face, as stated. This must be understood (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 3, Q & A 13).  
The [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1) of the [head](/topics/head2) is the mystical concept of an emanator, for a [fusion through collision](/topics/fusion-through-collision) occurs on its [partition](/topics/partition2), meaning a resistance to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe). Accordingly, it is the diametric opposite to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe), which is called an emanated being. How, then, can the one [devolve](/topics/devolvement) from the other? It is for this reason that the [head](/topics/head2), which is called [*Keter*](/topics/keter1), has two levels: The first is [*Atik*](/topics/atik), which is the resistance to [enclothing](/topics/enclothe). It is only the root to the [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim*, where [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) does not occur, because there was no [constriction](/topics/constriction) ([*tzimtzum*](/topics/tzimtzum1)) on the [light](/topics/light2) of *ĥassadim*, and thus it does not suffer from any [opacity](/topics/opacity) ([*ovyut*](/topics/ovyut)) on account of [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) at all. It is considered the root to the second [head](/topics/head2), which is the level of *Arikh Anpin*, the root of the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe), and it serves as the intermediary between emanator and emanated being, since it is the root for the [enclothing](/topics/enclothe) of the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma). By contrast, the emanator, which is [*Atik*](/topics/atik), is the opposite of the emanated being, as explained. Accordingly, every [*Keter*](/topics/keter1) is divided into two levels: [*Atik*](/topics/atik), which is only the root to the [light of giving](/topics/light-of-giving), *Arikh Anpin*, which is the root to the [light of *Ḥokhma*](/topics/light-of-hokhma) (*Talmud Eser Sefirot*, v. 8, Q & A 130).

description.he: אֱדום, שמשמעותו הצבע האָדום, הוא שמה של הממלכה שהקים אחיו של יעקב, עֵשָׂו, שהתורה מתארת כמי שנולד "אדמוני כולו". ממלכת אדום הייתה אחת מאויביו של עם ישראל ומאוחר יותר זוהתה עם הרומאים ועם המערב בכלל. ממלכת אדום שכנה בירדן של ימינו.
description.en: Edom, meaning “red,” is the name of the country founded by Jacob’s brother Esau, who the Bible says was born “red all over.” Edom was a rival of Israel and later became associated with the Romans and the West. Edom is located in present-day Jordan.

Tzitzit are the ritual fringes added to four-cornered garments. Four strings are threaded through each corner and folded over and knotted in order to produce eight fringes. Ideally, three of the strings should be white and the fourth should be azure, which is known as tekhelet in Hebrew.
description.he: ציצית היא מצווה מהתורה להוסיף פתילות לבגדים בעלי ארבע פינות. בכל אחת מן הפינות משחילים ארבעה חוטים, מקפלים וקושרים אותם עד שנוצרים שמונה קצוות חוט בכל פינה. שלושה מהחוטים בכל פינה צריכים להיות לבנים והרביעי בגוון תכלת מיוחד.

description.en: Another name for Hebrew.

Caleb (Kalev ben Yefuneh, in Hebrew) was one of the twelve spies sent to scout out Canaan soon after the Exodus. While most of the spies were intimidated by the Canaanites and their walled cities and returned discouraging reports, Caleb gave a more favorable account and was allowed to go into the promised land.
description.he: כלב בן יפונה היה אחד משנים־עשר המרגלים שיצאו לתור את ארץ כנען אחרי יציאת מצרים. בעוד רוב המרגלים חששו מפני הכנענים ועריהם הבצורות והביאו לעם דיווחים מייאשים, היה דיווחו של כלב מעודד, והותר לו להיכנס לארץ המובטחת.

description.en: Jewish customs and practices surrounding the death of an immediate family member – like burial and tearing one’s clothing – often have roots in biblical texts. Later Jewish works elaborate on how to act during different stages of mourning – before burial, the week following the burial, the month following death, and the year following death – and how practices may differ depending on the mourner's relationship to the deceased. Many Jewish mourning practices embody values such as  [honoring the dead](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/laws-of-honor-for-the-dead?tab=admin) and elevating their souls.
description.he: אֲבֵלוּת היא מצב רגשי ונפשי של התמודדות עם אובדן. בנוסף למימד הרגשי, האֲבֵלוּת ביהדות היא גם מצב הלכתי שנמשך שנה שרצופה במגוון הלכות ומנהגים. על בני משפחתו של הנפטר חלים דינים ברמות שונות של אבל, בהתאם לזמן שחלף מאז המוות. חובת האבלות הראשונה חלה עוד לפני הקבורה, כאשר בני המשפחה עסוקים בקבורת הנפטר - ולא בקיום מצוות. עם הקבורה, מתחילה תקופת האבלות של ימי השבעה. סימון הזמן הבא בימי האבל הוא אזכרת המת כאשר מלאו 30 יום למותו, ולאחר מכן בתום 11 חודשים. לאחר מכן נוהגים להזכיר את המת ביום השנה למותו.

description.en: Mount Sinai (Har Sinai) is famously where Moses and the Israelites heard the Ten Commandments and received the Torah. Although it was the location of this historic event, the mountain in the middle of the Sinai Desert was sacred only as long as God present.
description.he: הר סיני הוא המקום הידוע שבו משה ובני ישראל שמעו את עשרת הדיברות וקיבלו את התורה. אף שהמקום שימש את בני ישראל בשעתם הגדולה, ההר השוכן בלב מדבר סיני זכה לקדושה רק כאשר אלוהים התגלה מעליו.

description.en: Leah is one of the matriarchs of the Jewish people and the first wife of [Jacob](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/jacob). Her father tricked Jacob into marrying her and she suffered from the knowledge that she was unloved, in contrast to Jacob's beloved second wife, her sister [Rachel](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/rachel). She was blessed with six sons, who each became tribes in their own right, and one daughter.
description.he: לאה היא אחת מארבע האימהות של עם ישראל ואשתו הראשונה של יעקב. נישואיה ליעקב נבעו ממעשה הרמאות של אביה, לבן הארמי, שהשיא אותה ליעקב במקום את אחותה רחל. אהבת יעקב לרחל ולא לה ציערה אותה. היא בורכה בשישה בנים ובבת אחת, ומזרעם של השישה נוצרו שישה משבטי ישראל.

description.en: *Yirat Shamayim* — translated as “fear of heaven,” “awe of heaven,” or “reverence of heaven” — refers to an attitude toward God and is often considered an essential commandment and the basis of religious observance. In the Torah, “fear of God” connotes general ethical conduct, as may be the case in the Torah’s first use of the phrase in the story of [Abraham’s visit to Gerar](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.20.11?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en). Rabbinic literature and later Jewish texts expand on the concept of fearing God — claiming it is the one thing that God [does not control](https://www.sefaria.org/Berakhot.33b.23?lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) — analyze how fear of God intersects with [love of God](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/love-of-god1?tab=admin), and discuss how to achieve fear of God.
description.he: על פי רוב כוונת הביטוי יראת שמיים היא יראה מפני האל. יראת שמיים היא תכונה רוחנית חשובה ומרכזית המאגדת בתוכה פחד ויראה מן האל ובריאתו.

description.en: The seder is a ritual dinner and discussion held on the first or first two nights of Passover. Attendees retell the story of the exodus from Egypt and eat special foods to mark the occasion.
description.he: ליל הסדר הוא סעודה טקסית ושיחה בלילה הראשון (ובחו"ל גם השני) של חג הפסח. המשתתפים מספרים את סיפור יציאת מצרים ואוכלים מאכלים מיוחדים לציון האירוע.

description.en: The splitting of the Red Sea is an event described in [Exodus 14:1–15:21](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.14.1?ven=Tanakh:_The_Holy_Scriptures,_published_by_JPS&lang=he&aliyot=0), in which God miraculously splits the sea, and the Israelites cross through on dry land. When the Egyptians try to follow the Israelites, the sea closes in on them, and they drown.
description.he: קריעת ים סוף הוא אירוע שהתרחש במהלך יציאת מצרים המתואר בחומש שמות פרק י"ד. כדי להציל את ישראל מיד המצרים שרדפו אחריהם, אלוהים עשה נס גדול כאשר חצה את ים סוף ויצר מעבר של יבשה שמצדדיו חומות של מי הים. במעבר זה הלכו בני ישראל וכך ניצלו. כשהמצרים ניסו ללכת בעקבות בני ישראל ביבשה שבתוך הים, הים סגר עליהם והם טבעו בו.

description.en: Hillel was one of the most influential of the early sages, active toward the end of the first century BCE and the beginning of the first century CE. Coming from Babylon to the land of Israel, he became famous for his scholarship and his patient and tolerant manner. Bolstered by his Davidic lineage, he served as *nasi* (president) of the [*Sanhedrin*](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/sanhedrin?sort=Relevance&tab=notable-sources) (judicial assembly).
description.he: הלל היה אחד החכמים הראשונים, ומהפורים והמשפיעים ביניהם. הוא הגיע מבבל כדי ללמוד עם שמעיה ואבטליון, ונודע מהר מאוד בשל חוכמתו בתורה ואופיו הסבלני והסובלני. היותו צאצא של בית דוד הייתה בסיס לכהונתו כנשיא בתקופת שלטונו של הורדוס.

image_caption.en: Hillel, Window designed by E. M. Lilien for a stained-glass window in the Loge Bnei Brith in Hamburg. featuring a quote from Hillel in the Talmud, Shabbat 31a: 'which is hateful to you do not do to another"  Public domain.
image_caption.he: "הלל, חלון שתוכנן על ידי א. מ. ליליאן לחלון זכוכית צבעונית בלוז' בני ברית בהמבורג, עם ציטוט מהלל בתלמוד, שבת דף ל"א עמוד א': 'כל מה דשנאי לך לחברך לא תעביד."

description.en: R. Pinchas was a student of R. Yosi of Tiberias and a colleague of R. Huna and R. Hizkiyah. He lived in Tiberias and later moved to Tzippori.
description.he: רבי פנחס היה תלמידו של רבי יוסי מטבריא וחברותא של רב הונא ורב חזקיה. הוא חי בטבריה ובהמשך עבר לציפורי.

description.en: Jonah is the protagonist of the Book of Jonah. A reluctant prophet, he tried to avoid his instruction to prophecy destruction to Nineveh. He fleed by boat but was tossed overboard during a storm and swallowed by a great fish. After being saved by God, he went to Nineveh, whose people heeded his warnings and repented.
description.he: יונה, גיבורו של ספר יונה המקראי, הוא נביא מסויג. הוא נצטווה על ידי האל לנבא לבני העיר נינווה על חורבנה אם לא יחזרו אנשיה בתשובה, אבל ניסה להתחמק משליחות זו. הוא ברח באונייה ללב ים, הוטל ממנה בשעת סערה גדולה ונבלע על ידי דג גדול. לאחר שניצל באורח נס, הלך לנינווה להזהיר את אנשי העיר מפני החורבן, ואלה נענו לו וחזרו בתשובה.

description.en: Terumah is the tithe, or heave offering, taken from produce grown in the land of Israel and given to the [kohanim, or priests](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/priesthood?sort=Relevance&tab=notable-sources).
description.he: תרומה היא מתנה מקודשת הנלקחת מן היבול החקלאי בארץ ישראל וניתנת לכוהנים.

description.en: Childbirth is discussed throughout the Jewish textual tradition in a variety of contexts. The [charge to procreate](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.1.28?ven=The_Koren_Jerusalem_Bible&lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) is the first commandment in the Torah, and [painful childbirth](https://www.sefaria.org/Genesis.3.16?ven=The_Koren_Jerusalem_Bible&lang=bi&with=all&lang2=en) features as a punishment for Eve's role in eating from the tree of knowledge. Rabbinic sources discuss permitting otherwise prohibited actions for the sake of aiding childbirth, and sources of Jewish thought analyze the symbolic significance of the birthing process.
description.he: הלידה מופיעה לאורך מסורת מקורות היהדות במגוון הקשרים. ההולדה היא למעשה הציווי הראשון בתורה שניתן לאדם וחוה, ולידה המלווה בכאב היא העונש על חטאה של חוה באכילה מעץ הדעת. במקורות חז"ל ובספרות הלכתית ישנם  דיונים לגבי התרת איסורים שונים שעשויים לסייע ליולדת בשעת הלידה, ומקורות במחשבת ישראל מנתחים את המשמעות הסמלית של תהליך הלידה.

enBio.value: Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam, also know as Maimonides) was perhaps the greatest intellectual and spiritual figure of post-Talmudic Judaism. He wrote indispensable works of philosophy, Halacha, commentary, and responsa. Born in Spain, his family fled while he was still a youth. After an extended period in Morocco, he settled in Egypt, where he became Nagid (leader) of the Jewish community. His works were all foundational in their field. He was the first to produce a comprehensive commentary on the entire Mishnah. His great work of philosophy, Moreh Nevuchim, spawned an entire discipline and had incalculable influence upon enthusiastic promoters and vehement opponents alike. His code of law, Mishneh Torah, is the first and unsurpassed comprehensive code of Jewish law and practice. He also served as court physician to the Muslim leader Saladin. All of his works were written in Judeo-Arabic except for Mishneh Torah, which was written in a magnificent Hebrew. The precision of his expression is legendary. His descendents served as Negidim of Egypt for another four generations.

heBio.value: רבי משה בן מימון (רמב"ם) נחשב לאחד הגדולים בחכמתו וברוחניותו בתקופה הבתר-תלמודית. הוא כתב חיבורים חיוניים במחשבת ישראל, הלכה, פרשנות ושו"תים. נולד בספרד וברח עם משפחתו בעודו ילד. לאחר תקופה ממושכת במרוקו, הוא התיישב במצרים, ושם הפך לנגיד (מנהיג) של הקהילה היהודית. כל יצירתיו מהוות אבני יסוד בתחום שלהן. הרמב"ם היה הראשון שחיבר פרשנות מקיפה למשנה כולה. חיבורו במחשבת ישראל, מורה נבוכים, הביא לעולם דיסציפלינה שלמה והשפיע בצורה בלתי ניתנת לשיעור על תומכים נלהבים ועל מתנגדים חריפים כאחד. חיבורו ההלכתי, המשנה תורה, הוא החיבור ההלכתי מקיף שאין כמותו. הרמב"ם שימש גם כרופא חצר של המנהיג המוסלמי צלאח א-דין. כל יצירותיו נכתבו בערבית-יהודית, חוץ מהמשנה תורה, שנכתבה בעברית משובחת מאוד. הדיוק בצורת הביטוי שלו הוא אגדי. צאצאיו שימשו כנגידים של מצרים לארבעה דורות נוספים.

He was the first to produce a comprehensive commentary on the entire Mishnah. His great work of philosophy, *Moreh Nevukhim,* spawned an entire discipline and had incalculable influence upon enthusiastic promoters and vehement opponents alike. His code of law, *Mishneh Torah,* is the first and unsurpassed comprehensive code of Jewish law and practice. He also served as court physician to the Muslim leader Saladin. All of his works were written in Judeo-Arabic except for Mishneh Torah, which was written in a magnificent Hebrew. The precision of his expression is legendary. His descendants served as the leaders of the Egyptian Jewish community for another four generations.

description.en: Nature is discussed throughout Jewish literature in a variety of contexts. Many Jewish sources point to nature as a manifestation of godliness on earth, while others describe the importance of caring for our surroundings .
description.he: בספרות היהודית הטבע מופיע בהקשרים רבים. התבוננות בטבע מביאה להכרה בפלא בריאת העולם וביופי שבו. היהדות עוסקת בקשר של האדם והטבע, כאשר מצד אחד הוא כובש אותו ומצד שני שומר עליו. כמו כן, המקורות ספוגים בתיאורים ובדימויים רבים מעולם הטבע כמו: אפיקים בנגב ואייל עורג למים בספר תהילים, פריחת האביב בשיר השירים, משל האטד בספר שופטים ומשל הכרם של הנביא ישעיהו.

description.en: Jewish texts acknowledge the existence of poverty and greatly value attempts to alleviate it. Caring for the poor is a commandment in the Torah, and later halakhic (legal) authorities detail practical applications of the obligation. In sources of Jewish thought, poverty has been held up as a positive, refining quality as well as a potential punishment for sins. In any case, one is required to treat a poor person with respect and dignity.

description.en: The six extremities refers to the six directional edges or limits of every physical being. They are: Above, below, right, left, front, and back. These six extremities are paralleled by the six [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) that represent the [body](/topics/body3) of a [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1): [*Ḥesed*](/topics/hesed), [*Gevura*](/topics/gevura), [*Tiferet*](/topics/tiferet1), [*Netzaḥ*](/topics/netzah), [*Hod*](/topics/hod1), and [*Yesod*](/topics/yesod1). .

Shemot (“Names”) is the first Torah reading in the book of Exodus. It opens describing the enslavement of the Israelites in Egypt. Moses is born, placed in a basket on the Nile, and adopted into Pharaoh’s household. He later encounters God at a burning bush and begins his mission of demanding that Pharaoh let the Israelites go.
description.he: בפרשת שמות מתואר שיעבוד בני ישראל במצרים. משה נולד, ואימו מסתירה אותו בתיבה על היאור בשל גזרת פרעה להטביע את בני העברים ביאור. משה נלקח לבית פרעה וגדל שם, אך בורח ממצרים לאחר שהוא הורג מצרי. אלהים מתגלה אליו בסנה בוער באש ושולח אותו לבקש מפרעה לשחרר את בני ישראל.

description.en: A haftarah is a section from the Prophets section of the [Bible](https://www.sefaria.org/texts/Tanakh), commonly read aloud in synagogues following the Torah reading on Shabbat and holidays. Each Torah portion has a corresponding and generally thematically connected haftarah portion, though the exact section of Prophets can vary by communal custom.

description.en: Bereshit ("In the Beginning”) is the first parashah in the annual Torah reading cycle, which restarts at the beginning of the book of Genesis. The reading begins with God’s creation of the world. The first people, Adam and Eve, eat from the Tree of Knowledge and are then banished from the Garden of Eden. Their elder son, Cain, kills their younger son, Abel, and Cain is destined to a life of wandering.
description.he: פרשת בראשית, הפרשה הראשונה בתורה, מתארת את ראשיתו של העולם. אלוהים בורא את העולם בשישה ימים ונח ביום השביעי. הוא מניח את האדם בגן עדן ומצווה עליו ליהנות מפירות הגן מלבד מפרי עץ הדעת. בעצת הנחש חוה ואדם אוכלים מעץ הדעת, ולכן מגורשים מגן עדן. בנם הבכור קין הורג את אחיו הצעיר הבל, וקין נידון להיות נע ונד בארץ.

description.en: The giving of the Torah is an event described in [Exodus 19–20](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.19?lang=bi&aliyot=0) and [Deuteronomy 5](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.5.2?lang=bi&aliyot=0), in which God gives the Torah to the Israelites at Mount Sinai. Accompanied by fire, smoke, a cloud, thunder, and lightning, God commands the Ten Commandments. The event is considered a foundational moment in Jewish tradition and is celebrated on the holiday of [Shavuot](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/shavuot?tab=sources).
description.he: מתן תורה (המכונה גם מַעֲמַד הַר סִינָי) מתייחס לאירוע מכונן בהיסטוריה היהודית בו, על פי המסורת, נתן אלוהים את התורה לבני ישראל בהר סִינָי.  מאורע זה מסמל את מערכת היחסים המיוחדת בין אלוהים לעם היהודי, וכן את תפקידה המרכזי של התורה בחיים היהודיים. לכן, מתן תורה הוא מאורע משמעותי ביותר בלוח השנה היהודי, והוא נחגג  כחלק מחג השבועות בתפילות מיוחדות, קריאת התורה ומנהגים מסורתיים הכוללים אכילת מאכלי חלב, לימוד תורה במשך כל הלילה, ועוד.

description.en: Dreams are discussed throughout Jewish literature in a variety of contexts. The Bible features several dreams, such as those in the narrative of Joseph in Genesis. Generations of Jewish sources have analyzed the significance and role of dreams.

description.en: Rain features prominently throughout the Jewish textual tradition. In the Torah, it is repeatedly described as a marker of God's blessing in the land of Israel. Jewish liturgy incorporates special prayers for rain, and rabbinic and philosophical sources are replete with discussions of the significance of rain and the laws and customs associated with asking for rain.
description.he: הגשם הוא צורך בסיסי של האנושות והעולם וחשיבותו בולטת במיוחד בארץ ישראל התלויה במי הגשמים. מסיבה זו מקורות היהדות, מהקדומים ועד למאוחרים, עוסקים רבות בגשם.  בפסוקי התורה הגשם הוא ברכה המשמשת סימן ואישור לקיום מצוות התורה על ידי עם ישראל. בנוסחי התפילה השונים חוברו תפילות מיוחדות לבקשת גשמים, וגם מקורות דרשניים והגותיים מאוחרים יותר גדושים בדיונים על משמעות הגשם ועל ההלכות והמנהגים הקשורים בו.

description.en: *Abba* and *Ima Ila'in* (literally "supernal father and mother") is the name for the [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) formed out of the first three [*sefirot*](/topics/sefirot) of the entire [level](/topics/level) of [*Bina*](/topics/bina3) that was ejected from the [head](/topics/head2) of [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1) as a result of the [second constriction](/topics/second-constriction) and the ascent of [*Malkhut*](/topics/malkhut1). This [*partzuf*](/topics/partzuf1) [enclothes](/topics/enclothe) [*Arikh Anpin*](/topics/arikh-anpin1) from the [mouth](/topics/mouth1) to the chest.

description.en: During the tumultuous reign of Alexander Yannai, the third pair of the Zugot, Yehudah ben Tabbai and Shimon ben Shetach, faced significant challenges. Despite being Yannai's brother-in-law, Shimon had to go into hiding during Yannai's persecution of the Pharisees, while Yehudah fled to Egypt. Nonetheless, Shimon successfully wrested control of the Sanhedrin from the Sadducees.
description.he: הזוג השלישי, יהודה בן טבאי ושמעון בן שטח, כיהנו בתקופה הסוערת של שלטון אלכסנדר ינאי. אף ששמעון היה גיסו של ינאי, הוא נאלץ להסתתר בשיאה של רדיפת הפרושים על ידי ינאי, ויהודה ברח למצרים. למרות זאת הצליח שמעון להשיג שליטה על הסנהדרין במקום הצדוקים.

description.en: The "Ten Commandments" or "Ten Utterances" are the group of the commandments given to the Israelites at Mount Sinai in a constitutive moment of divine revelation to all of the children of Israel. The first set of five commandments establish the rules of God's relationship with humanity, and the second set of five are between people and other people. The Ten Commandments appear twice in the Torah: first, when they are given at Sinai, in [Exodus 20](https://www.sefaria.org/Exodus.20?lang=bi&aliyot=0) and again in [Deuteronomy 5](https://www.sefaria.org/Deuteronomy.5.7?lang=bi&aliyot=0), in Moses' retelling of the earlier narrative.

description.en: Atonement, or kapparah in Hebrew, is the process of bringing about forgiveness for a sin. In the Jewish textual tradition, atonement may be achieved through repentance, prayer, sacrifice, punishment, the rituals of [Yom Kippur](https://www.sefaria.org/topics/yom-kippur?sort=Relevance&tab=sources), and other methods.

The Torah, for example, instructs the individual not to harbor hatred in one's heart, rabbinic texts discuss under what conditions thoughts are rendered legally significant, and chasidic texts offer guidance on maintaining positive thinking.
